question_details.query: To mitigate primate crop-raiding, what is the relative effectiveness of chasing primates with loud noises versus using bright lights?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One controlled, replicated, before-and-after study in Indonesia found that using noise deterrents along with tree nets reduced crop raiding by orangutans, and one study in the Democratic Republic of Congo found that chasing gorillas and using random noise resulted in their return from plantations to areas close to protected forest [1449]. No evidence was found on the effects of humans chasing primates using bright light to deter crop-raiding [1450].
summary_statements: A study in Indonesia found that using noise deterrents along with tree nets reduced crop raiding by orangutans.
A study in the Democratic Republic of Congo found that chasing gorillas and using random noise resulted in the gorillas' return from plantations to areas close to protected forest.
No evidence was found on the effects of humans chasing primates using bright light to deter crop-raiding.

question_details.query: What is the evidence base for conservation actions designed to mitigate the impacts of commercial logging on primate populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across identified actions intended to mitigate impacts of commercial logging on primates, the evidence base currently reports no studies directly testing their effects on primate populations: using set‑asides for primate protection within logging areas (no evidence) [1497]; reducing the size of forestry teams to employees only, excluding family members (no evidence) [1499]; certifying forest concessions and marketing products as “primate friendly” (no evidence) [1500]; implementing small and dispersed logging compartments (no evidence) [1487]; thinning trees within forests (no evidence) [1491]; providing domestic meat to logging company workers to reduce hunting (no evidence) [1501]; and avoiding slashing climbers/lianas, trees housing them, hemi‑epiphytic figs, and ground vegetation (no evidence) [1493].
summary_statements: The evidence base currently reports no studies directly testing the effects on primate populations of actions intended to mitigate the impacts of commercial logging.
There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects on primate populations of using set-asides for primate protection within logging areas.
There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects on primate populations of reducing the size of forestry teams to employees only, excluding family members.
There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects on primate populations of certifying forest concessions and marketing products as “primate friendly”.
There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects on primate populations of implementing small and dispersed logging compartments.
There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects on primate populations of thinning trees within forests.
There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects on primate populations of providing domestic meat to logging company workers to reduce hunting.
There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects on primate populations of avoiding slashing climbers/lianas, trees housing them, hemi-epiphytic figs, and ground vegetation.

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and harms of running tourism projects focused on wild primates?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across multiple studies, tourism projects were associated with both potential benefits and harms for wild primates, often alongside other interventions: Mountain gorilla numbers increased after touristic projects were initiated in Rwanda, Uganda and the Republic of Congo, including a 22% rise in immature gorillas and a 30% decline in snares at one site [1512]. A black howler monkey population in Belize increased by 138% over 13 years after a tourism project was implemented [1512]. In contrast, numbers of Tana River red colobus and crested mangabeys in Kenya decreased despite a tourism project [1512]. An intensive tourism project for Tibetan macaques in China that included food provisioning and range restrictions increased stress levels, with infant mortality reaching 100% in some years [1512]. Following a tourism project in Madagascar, population size and/or body size and group size declined for two lemur species while one lemur species increased [1512]. Additional evidence linked to tourism visitation practices reported that mountain gorilla numbers increased by 168% over 41 years while being visited by researchers and visitors wearing face-masks, keeping safety distances, and restricting visits to healthy individuals, alongside other interventions [1537, 1538, 1546]. No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of promoting mammal-related ecotourism on mammal populations [2624].
summary_statements: Across multiple studies, tourism projects were associated with both potential benefits and harms for wild primates.
Tourism projects for wild primates often occurred alongside other interventions.
Mountain gorilla numbers increased after touristic projects were initiated in Rwanda, Uganda and the Republic of Congo.
One tourism project site for mountain gorillas saw a 22% rise in immature gorillas and a 30% decline in snares.
A black howler monkey population in Belize increased by 138% over 13 years after a tourism project was implemented.
The numbers of Tana River red colobus and crested mangabeys in Kenya decreased despite a tourism project.
An intensive tourism project for Tibetan macaques in China that included food provisioning and range restrictions increased the primates' stress levels.
Following the intensive tourism project for Tibetan macaques in China, infant mortality for the macaques reached 100% in some years.
Following a tourism project in Madagascar, population size, body size, and/or group size declined for two lemur species.
Following a tourism project in Madagascar, one lemur species increased.

Mountain gorilla numbers increased by 168% over 41 years while being visited by researchers and visitors wearing face-masks, keeping safety distances, and restricting visits to healthy individuals, alongside other interventions.
No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of promoting mammal-related ecotourism on mammal populations.

question_details.query: What are the typical outcomes when primates are reintroduced into habitats where the same species is already present?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across multiple studies, outcomes included: majority survival of reintroduced chimpanzees for at least 1–5 years in Guinea and the Republic of Congo (alongside other interventions) [1591]; an individual chimpanzee repeatedly returning to human settlements in Uganda and another being reunited with its mother in Senegal [1591]; majority survival of reintroduced orangutans in Malaysia, but a reintroduced orangutan population declining over 33 years in a controlled study [1591]; population-level changes with increases reported in Belize five years post-reintroduction and declines reported in Thailand post-reintroduction [1591]; variable survival across sites, with minority survival for at least 15 weeks to 7 years in several countries and majority survival for at least 2 months to 1 year in others [1591]; reintroduced primates showing similar diets and behaviors to wild conspecifics in controlled studies in Madagascar and Indonesia [1591]; and a reintroduced muriqui rejoining a wild group in Brazil [1591].
summary_statements: The majority of reintroduced chimpanzees survived for at least 1–5 years in Guinea and the Republic of Congo.
The survival of reintroduced chimpanzees in Guinea and the Republic of Congo occurred alongside other interventions.
An individual chimpanzee repeatedly returned to human settlements in Uganda.
A reintroduced chimpanzee was reunited with its mother in Senegal.
The majority of reintroduced orangutans survived in Malaysia.
A reintroduced orangutan population declined over 33 years in a controlled study.
Primate population increases were reported in Belize five years post-reintroduction.
Primate population declines were reported in Thailand post-reintroduction.
Survival of reintroduced primates was variable across different sites.
In several countries, a minority of reintroduced primates survived for at least 15 weeks to 7 years.
In other countries, a majority of reintroduced primates survived for at least 2 months to 1 year.
Reintroduced primates showed diets and behaviors similar to wild primates of the same species in controlled studies in Madagascar and Indonesia.
A reintroduced muriqui rejoined a wild group in Brazil.

question_details.query: For what length of time have translocated primate populations been observed to survive post-release?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Reported post-release survival or persistence durations for translocated or reintroduced primates include: at least 15 weeks to seven years for some group reintroductions, with many cases reporting survival between two and thirty months [1567]; over three months for quarantined orangutans and at least four months for reintroduced black lion tamarins, with some orangutans surviving the first three months and chimpanzees surviving over 1–5 years [1553, 1541]; more than 10 years for reintroduced gorillas following quarantine [1541]; 16 years for a translocated olive baboon population when veterinary screening and other interventions were used [1553]; persistence of primate populations for 4–55 years after group reintroductions in Madagascar and India [1567]; and one orangutan population persisting while decreasing by 33% over a 40-year period despite quarantine [1541].
summary_statements: For some primate group reintroductions, post-release survival has been reported to be at least 15 weeks to seven years.
In many cases, translocated or reintroduced primates have been reported to survive between two and thirty months.
Quarantined orangutans have been observed to survive for over three months post-release.
Reintroduced black lion tamarins have been observed to survive for at least four months.
Some orangutans have been observed to survive the first three months post-release.
Chimpanzees have been observed to survive for over one to five years post-release.
Reintroduced gorillas have been observed to survive for more than 10 years following quarantine.
A translocated olive baboon population survived for 16 years when veterinary screening and other interventions were used.
Primate populations in Madagascar and India have persisted for 4 to 55 years after group reintroductions.
One orangutan population persisted over a 40-year period despite quarantine.
One orangutan population decreased by 33% over a 40-year period despite quarantine.

question_details.query: What are the effects of installing different types of bridges to mitigate road impacts on arboreal and terrestrial primates?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence specific to primates shows that installing rope or pole (canopy) bridges has facilitated crossings and, in one case, population increase for arboreal primates: black lion tamarins and capuchins used a pole bridge to cross a road; a black howler monkey population increased after pole bridges were installed over man-made gaps; and six monitored lemur species used bridges to cross roads and pipelines [1457]. For green bridges (overpasses), no studies were found that directly tested effects on primate populations [1456].
summary_statements: Evidence specific to primates shows that installing rope or pole (canopy) bridges has facilitated crossings for arboreal primates.
In one case, the installation of rope or pole (canopy) bridges led to a population increase for arboreal primates.
Black lion tamarins and capuchins used a pole bridge to cross a road.
A black howler monkey population increased after pole bridges were installed over man-made gaps.
Six monitored lemur species used bridges to cross roads and pipelines.
No studies were found that directly tested the effects of green bridges (overpasses) on primate populations.

question_details.query: What actions can be taken at research and tourism sites to reduce the risk of disease transmission from humans to wild primates?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Identified actions include: ensuring researchers/tourists are up-to-date with vaccinations and not visiting when unwell, with one before-and-after study reporting mountain gorilla numbers increased by 168% over 41 years under such measures, alongside other interventions, while a controlled study found a reintroduced orangutan population decreased by 33% over 33 years despite staff/volunteer medical checks, alongside other interventions (1546). Limiting the time researchers/tourists spend with habituated animals was associated with reintroduced Sumatran orangutans behaving more like wild conspecifics in one controlled study, and mountain gorilla numbers increasing by 168% over 41 years in one before-and-after study, both alongside other interventions (1539). Wearing face-masks by visitors/researchers was reported alongside the successful reunion of a confiscated young chimpanzee with its mother in Uganda in one study, and with mountain gorilla numbers increasing by 168% over 41 years in one before-and-after study, both alongside other interventions (1537). Keeping a safety distance from habituated animals was reported with most reintroduced chimpanzees surviving over five years in one before-and-after study, a 33% decline in reintroduced orangutans over 31 years in one controlled study despite distance rules, and a 168% increase in mountain gorillas over 41 years in one before-and-after study, all alongside other interventions (1538). Additional proposed actions with no direct quantitative evidence found include: avoiding contact between wild primates and human-raised primates (1555); implementing quarantine for people arriving at and leaving sites (1540); implementing health programmes for local communities (1557); not allowing people to consume food where primates can view them (1508); wearing gloves when handling primate food or tool items (1548); installing primate-proof garbage bins (1505); and controlling potential ‘reservoir’ species to reduce pathogen sources (1552).
summary_statements: Ensuring researchers and tourists are up-to-date with vaccinations is an identified action to reduce disease transmission risk from humans to wild primates.
Ensuring researchers and tourists do not visit wild primates when unwell is an identified action to reduce disease transmission risk from humans to wild primates.
One before-and-after study reported mountain gorilla numbers increased by 168% over 41 years under health measures for visitors, alongside other interventions.
A controlled study found a reintroduced orangutan population decreased by 33% over 33 years despite staff and volunteer medical checks, alongside other interventions.
Limiting the time researchers and tourists spend with habituated animals was associated with reintroduced Sumatran orangutans behaving more like wild orangutans in one controlled study.
Limiting the time researchers and tourists spend with habituated animals was associated with mountain gorilla numbers increasing by 168% over 41 years in one before-and-after study.
Wearing face-masks by visitors and researchers was reported alongside the successful reunion of a confiscated young chimpanzee with its mother in Uganda in one study.
The use of face-masks by visitors and researchers was reported alongside mountain gorilla numbers increasing by 168% over 41 years in one before-and-after study.
Keeping a safety distance from habituated animals was reported with most reintroduced chimpanzees surviving over five years in one before-and-after study.
A 33% decline in reintroduced orangutans over 31 years was reported in one controlled study despite distance rules.
Keeping a safety distance from habituated animals was reported with a 168% increase in mountain gorillas over 41 years in one before-and-after study.
Additional proposed actions with no direct quantitative evidence found include avoiding contact between wild primates and human-raised primates.
Implementing quarantine for people arriving at and leaving research and tourism sites is a proposed action with no direct quantitative evidence found.
Implementing health programmes for local communities is a proposed action with no direct quantitative evidence found.
Not allowing people to consume food where primates can view the people is a proposed action with no direct quantitative evidence found.
Wearing gloves when handling primate food or tool items is a proposed action with no direct quantitative evidence found.
Installing primate-proof garbage bins is a proposed action with no direct quantitative evidence found.
Controlling potential ‘reservoir’ species to reduce pathogen sources is a proposed action with no direct quantitative evidence found.

question_details.query: What are the comparative outcomes of different supplementary feeding strategies for primates?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Providing supplementary food for a limited period (e.g., around reintroduction) was associated with mixed outcomes: increases in a chimpanzee population after two months of feeding in Tanzania; a decline in a golden lion tamarin population after one year in Brazil; retrieval and reintegration of an abandoned infant muriqui in Brazil; minority survival in some reintroductions in Brazil, Madagascar and South Africa; majority survival in other cases including chimpanzees in Guinea (≥27 months), primates in Gabon, South Africa and Vietnam, and lowland gorillas in Gabon and the Republic of Congo (≥9 months to 4 years) [1528]. Providing supplementary food only during resource-scarce periods was associated with majority survival of introduced chimpanzees for at least five years in the Republic of Congo, survival of wild olive baboons for at least 17 years post-translocation in Kenya, and black-and-white ruffed lemurs maintaining a diet similar to wild individuals in Madagascar [1527]. In captive-focused feeding strategies, providing cut branches (browse) led captive gorillas in the Netherlands and Germany to use processing skills seen in wild gorillas [1332], and increasing the number of feeds per day increased time spent feeding in chimpanzees but also increased hair eating in baboons in Japan and the USA [1337].
summary_statements: Providing supplementary food for a limited period was associated with increases in a chimpanzee population after two months of feeding in Tanzania.
Providing supplementary food for a limited period was associated with a decline in a golden lion tamarin population after one year in Brazil.
Providing supplementary food for a limited period was associated with the retrieval and reintegration of an abandoned infant muriqui in Brazil.
Providing supplementary food for a limited period was associated with minority survival in some primate reintroductions in Brazil, Madagascar and South Africa.

In other cases, providing supplementary food for a limited period was associated with majority survival of chimpanzees in Guinea, primates in Gabon, South Africa and Vietnam, and lowland gorillas in Gabon and the Republic of Congo.
Providing supplementary food only during resource-scarce periods was associated with the majority survival of introduced chimpanzees for at least five years in the Republic of Congo.
Providing supplementary food only during resource-scarce periods was associated with the survival of wild olive baboons for at least 17 years post-translocation in Kenya.
Providing supplementary food only during resource-scarce periods was associated with black-and-white ruffed lemurs maintaining a diet similar to wild individuals in Madagascar.
In captive-focused feeding strategies, providing cut branches led captive gorillas in the Netherlands and Germany to use processing skills seen in wild gorillas.
Increasing the number of feeds per day increased the time spent feeding in chimpanzees.
Increasing the number of feeds per day increased hair eating in baboons in Japan and the USA.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of providing financial incentives to farmers to encourage primate conservation on agricultural land?
What are the documented outcomes of translocating primates as a conflict management tool?
How does a permanent human presence at a site influence the success of primate conservation efforts?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence on permanent human presence shows mixed outcomes across primate contexts: A before-and-after study in Kenya reported declines in Tana River red colobus and crested mangabeys despite permanent reserve staff presence, while a study in Thailand found a reintroduced lar gibbon population declined over three years under permanent staff presence; conversely, a before-and-after study in Belize found black howler monkeys increased by 138% over 13 years after introducing permanent staff, and studies in Congo and Gabon reported that most reintroduced central chimpanzees (five years) and western lowland gorillas (nine months) survived when accompanied by reserve staff [1517]. Habituation to human presence showed varied results: an introduced golden lion tamarin population declined after one year, whereas most introduced black-and-white ruffed lemurs and diademed sifakas survived over 30 months, and a mountain gorilla population increased over 41 years following habituation, all alongside other interventions [1519]. Continuous on-site veterinary monitoring was associated with a 168% increase in mountain gorilla population size over 41 years, alongside other interventions [1554]. Training anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated with no gorillas killed over 21 months, increased numbers of immature gorillas, growth of a hoolock gibbon population, and a three-year period with no incidents of primate poaching, all alongside other interventions [1477]. Implementing monitoring/surveillance systems to guide law enforcement was followed by increased observations of gorillas and chimpanzees in Nigeria [1481].
summary_statements: Evidence on permanent human presence shows mixed outcomes across primate contexts.
A study in Kenya reported declines in Tana River red colobus and crested mangabeys despite the permanent presence of reserve staff.
A study in Thailand found a reintroduced lar gibbon population declined over three years under permanent staff presence.
A study in Belize found black howler monkeys increased by 138% over 13 years after permanent staff were introduced.
Studies in Congo reported that most reintroduced central chimpanzees survived over five years when accompanied by reserve staff.
Studies in Gabon reported that most reintroduced western lowland gorillas survived over nine months when accompanied by reserve staff.
Habituation of primates to human presence has shown varied results for conservation.
An introduced golden lion tamarin population declined after one year of habituation to human presence, alongside other interventions.
Most introduced black-and-white ruffed lemurs survived over 30 months following habituation to human presence, alongside other interventions.
Most introduced diademed sifakas survived over 30 months following habituation to human presence, alongside other interventions.
A mountain gorilla population increased over 41 years following habituation to human presence, alongside other interventions.
Continuous on-site veterinary monitoring was associated with a 168% increase in mountain gorilla population size over 41 years, alongside other interventions.
Training anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated with no gorillas being killed over 21 months, alongside other interventions.
Training anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated with increased numbers of immature gorillas, alongside other interventions.
Training anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated with the growth of a hoolock gibbon population, alongside other interventions.
Training anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated with a three-year period with no incidents of primate poaching, alongside other interventions.
Implementing monitoring and surveillance systems to guide law enforcement in Nigeria was followed by increased observations of gorillas and chimpanzees.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for the success of captive breeding and reintroduction programs based on the primates' rearing environment?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One before-and-after study in Brazil found that only two out of three reintroduced black lion tamarins survived over four months, despite being raised in a free-ranging environment, alongside other interventions (1596). One controlled study in Madagascar found that the diet of reintroduced black-and-white ruffed lemurs born and raised in a free-ranging environment, alongside other interventions, overlapped with that of wild lemurs (1596). One before-and-after study in Brazil found that most reintroduced golden lion tamarins born and reared in cages, alongside other interventions, did not survive over seven years or had a higher mortality than wild-born tamarins (1594). One controlled study in French Guiana found that more squirrel monkeys born and reared in cages, alongside other interventions, died or were returned to captivity post-reintroduction compared to wild-born monkeys (1594). One controlled study in Madagascar found that the diet of reintroduced black-and-white ruffed lemurs born and reared in cages, alongside other interventions, did not overlap with that of wild lemurs (1594). One controlled study in Madagascar found that the diet of reintroduced black-and-white ruffed lemurs with limited free-ranging experience, alongside other interventions, overlapped with that of wild lemurs; one before-and-after study in Madagascar found that most of these lemurs died over five years (1595). One before-and-after and site comparison study and one before-and-after study in the Republic of Congo and Gabon found that most reintroduced western lowland gorillas with limited free-ranging experience, alongside other interventions, survived over periods between nine months and four years (1595).
summary_statements: A study in Brazil found that only two out of three reintroduced black lion tamarins survived over four months, despite being raised in a free-ranging environment alongside other interventions.

A study in Madagascar found that the diet of reintroduced black-and-white ruffed lemurs born and raised in a free-ranging environment, alongside other interventions, overlapped with that of wild lemurs.
A study in Brazil found that most reintroduced golden lion tamarins born and reared in cages, alongside other interventions, did not survive over seven years.
A study in Brazil found that reintroduced golden lion tamarins born and reared in cages had a higher mortality than wild-born tamarins.
A study in French Guiana found that more squirrel monkeys born and reared in cages, alongside other interventions, died post-reintroduction compared to wild-born monkeys.
A study in French Guiana found that more squirrel monkeys born and reared in cages, alongside other interventions, were returned to captivity post-reintroduction compared to wild-born monkeys.
A study in Madagascar found that the diet of reintroduced black-and-white ruffed lemurs born and reared in cages, alongside other interventions, did not overlap with that of wild lemurs.
A study in Madagascar found that the diet of reintroduced black-and-white ruffed lemurs with limited free-ranging experience, alongside other interventions, overlapped with that of wild lemurs.
A study in Madagascar found that most reintroduced black-and-white ruffed lemurs with limited free-ranging experience died over five years.

Studies in the Republic of Congo and Gabon found that most reintroduced western lowland gorillas with limited free-ranging experience, alongside other interventions, survived over periods between nine months and four years.

question_details.query: What are the documented outcomes of providing artificial non-food resources like nesting sites and water sources for primates?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence specific to primates documents that: (1) A before-and-after study in Brazil found a translocated lion tamarin population declined after artificial nest boxes were provided, alongside other interventions [1530]. (2) A before-and-after study in Brazil found that a majority of reintroduced golden lion tamarins died seven years after artificial nest boxes were provided, alongside other interventions [1530]. (3) A before-and-after study in Gabon found that a majority of juvenile western lowland gorillas survived for at least seven years after nesting platforms were provided, alongside other interventions [1530]. No primate-specific outcomes for artificial water sources were identified in the retrieved action documents.
summary_statements: A before-and-after study in Brazil found a translocated lion tamarin population declined after artificial nest boxes were provided, alongside other interventions.
A before-and-after study in Brazil found that a majority of reintroduced golden lion tamarins died seven years after artificial nest boxes were provided, alongside other interventions.
A before-and-after study in Gabon found that a majority of juvenile western lowland gorillas survived for at least seven years after nesting platforms were provided, alongside other interventions.
No primate-specific outcomes for artificial water sources were identified in the retrieved action documents.

question_details.query: To manage human-wildlife conflict in residential areas, what are the benefits and potential drawbacks of relocating primates?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence directly on relocating primates is limited: one source reported no studies quantifying effects of relocating primates to non-residential areas (1423). Reported potential benefits from cases where problem primates were removed and relocated, alongside other interventions, include survival at or near non-residential release sites for at least four years for translocated rhesus monkeys (India) and western lowland gorillas (Republic of Congo and Gabon), and long-term survival for crop-raiding olive baboons comparable to non-translocated populations after 16 years (Kenya) (1422). Potential drawbacks, drawn from broader mammal translocations in residential-conflict contexts, include lower survival after translocation compared to non-translocated animals in several species (e.g., grizzly bears and some deer; most translocated Amur tigers not surviving one year) and individuals returning to capture locations and/or continuing nuisance behavior, sometimes repeatedly (bears), with one case of increased attacks on humans and livestock after leopard translocation; though one study found translocated brown bears occurred less often inside high-conflict areas than non-translocated bears (2336). Additional evidence on habituated mammals indicates that nearly half of translocated nuisance black bears returned to capture sites, while returns were less likely when younger bears were moved farther and across barriers (2341).
summary_statements: Evidence directly on relocating primates is limited.
One source reported no studies quantifying the effects of relocating primates to non-residential areas.
A reported potential benefit of relocating problem primates is survival at or near non-residential release sites.
Translocated rhesus monkeys in India survived for at least four years at or near non-residential release sites.
Translocated western lowland gorillas in the Republic of Congo and Gabon survived for at least four years at or near non-residential release sites.
Relocated crop-raiding olive baboons in Kenya had long-term survival comparable to non-translocated populations after 16 years.
Potential drawbacks from broader mammal translocations include lower survival after translocation compared to non-translocated animals.
Translocated grizzly bears, some deer, and most translocated Amur tigers showed lower survival rates after translocation.
A potential drawback of translocation is individuals returning to capture locations and/or continuing nuisance behavior.
Translocated bears sometimes repeatedly return to capture locations and continue nuisance behavior.
One case of leopard translocation led to increased attacks on humans and livestock.
One study found translocated brown bears occurred less often inside high-conflict areas than non-translocated bears.
Nearly half of translocated nuisance black bears returned to their capture sites.
Returns to capture sites were less likely when younger bears were moved farther away.
Returns to capture sites were less likely when bears were moved across barriers.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for relocating 'problem' primates versus relocating primates from residential areas for conservation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence for relocating ‘problem’ primates includes: a replicated, before-and-after study in India where translocated ‘problem’ rhesus monkeys, alongside other interventions, survived and remained at release sites for at least four years; a controlled, before-and-after study in Kenya where crop‑raiding olive baboons translocated from farmland, alongside other interventions, mostly survived after 16 years with survival rates similar to non‑translocated populations; and a before‑and‑after, site comparison study in the Republic of Congo and Gabon where 84% of relocated ‘problem’ western lowland gorillas, alongside other interventions, survived for at least four years [1422]. For relocating primates to non‑residential areas, no studies were found that directly and quantitatively tested effects on primate populations, so no evidence of effectiveness or harm is available [1423].
summary_statements: A replicated, before-and-after study in India found that translocated ‘problem’ rhesus monkeys, alongside other interventions, survived and remained at release sites for at least four years.
A controlled, before-and-after study in Kenya showed that crop-raiding olive baboons translocated from farmland, alongside other interventions, mostly survived after 16 years.
The survival rates of the translocated olive baboons in the Kenya study were similar to non-translocated populations.

A before-and-after, site comparison study in the Republic of Congo and Gabon found that 84% of relocated ‘problem’ western lowland gorillas, alongside other interventions, survived for at least four years.
No studies were found that directly and quantitatively tested the effects on primate populations for relocating primates to non-residential areas.
No evidence of effectiveness or harm is available for relocating primates to non-residential areas.

question_details.query: To reduce primate reliance on human food in tourist areas, what management actions are available and what is their known effectiveness?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Available actions and known effectiveness include: Implement a ‘no-feeding of wild primates’ policy: one controlled, before-and-after study in Japan found several previously increasing Japanese macaque populations declined in size and productivity after limiting and then prohibiting food provisioning [1502]. Put up signs to warn people about not feeding primates: one review in Japan found aggressive interactions between Japanese macaques and humans declined after prohibiting tourists from feeding monkeys [1507]. Do not allow people to consume food within natural areas where primates can view them: no evidence for effects on primate populations [1508]. Install ‘primate-proof’ garbage bins: no evidence for effects on primate populations [1505]. Remove human food waste that may potentially serve as food sources for primates: no evidence for effects on primate populations [1561]. Implement multimedia campaigns using theatre, film, print media, discussions: two before-and-after studies in Belize found black howler monkey numbers increased by 61–138% over 3–13 years after a multimedia campaign or opening a museum for wildlife education, alongside other interventions; two before-and-after studies in Brazil and Colombia found education programs focusing on tamarins improved attitudes and knowledge; one study in the Republic of Congo found large numbers of people were informed about lowland gorillas through theatre and film; one before-and-after study in Madagascar found poaching of diademed sifakas and black and white ruffed lemurs appeared to have ceased after distributing conservation books in schools; one before-and-after study in India found hoolock gibbon numbers increased by 66% over five years after an education and awareness programme, alongside other interventions; one before-and-after study in four African countries found visitors’ knowledge about primates increased after an education programme [1571].
summary_statements: A controlled, before-and-after study in Japan found that several previously increasing Japanese macaque populations declined in size and productivity after limiting and then prohibiting food provisioning.
A review in Japan found that aggressive interactions between Japanese macaques and humans declined after prohibiting tourists from feeding monkeys.
There is no evidence for effects on primate populations from not allowing people to consume food within natural areas where primates can view them.
There is no evidence for effects on primate populations from installing ‘primate-proof’ garbage bins.
There is no evidence for effects on primate populations from removing human food waste that may potentially serve as food sources for primates.

Two before-and-after studies in Belize found black howler monkey numbers increased by 61–138% over 3–13 years after a multimedia campaign or opening a museum for wildlife education, alongside other interventions.
Two before-and-after studies in Brazil and Colombia found that education programs focusing on tamarins improved attitudes and knowledge.
One study in the Republic of Congo found that large numbers of people were informed about lowland gorillas through theatre and film.
One before-and-after study in Madagascar found poaching of diademed sifakas and black and white ruffed lemurs appeared to have ceased after the distribution of conservation books in schools.
A before-and-after study in India found hoolock gibbon numbers increased by 66% over five years after an education and awareness programme was implemented alongside other interventions.
A before-and-after study in four African countries found that visitors’ knowledge about primates increased after an education programme.

question_details.query: What is the evidence base for actions to mitigate the impacts of the mining industry on primate populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The available action documents report no evidence for the effects of several proposed mining-related mitigation actions on primate populations, including: minimizing ground vibrations from open-cast mining [1451]; using set-aside areas of natural habitat for primate protection within mining areas [1453]; certifying mines and marketing products as “primate friendly” [1454]; implementing a minimum number of roads (and minimizing secondary roads) to reach extraction sites [1462]; and establishing no-mining zones in/near watersheds to preserve water levels and quality [1452].
summary_statements: The available action documents report no evidence for the effects of several proposed mining-related mitigation actions on primate populations.
Available action documents report no evidence for the effects on primate populations of minimizing ground vibrations from open-cast mining.
Available action documents report no evidence for the effects on primate populations of using set-aside areas of natural habitat for primate protection within mining areas.
Available action documents report no evidence for the effects on primate populations of certifying mines and marketing products as “primate friendly”.
Available action documents report no evidence for the effects on primate populations of implementing a minimum number of roads and minimizing secondary roads to reach extraction sites.
Available action documents report no evidence for the effects on primate populations of establishing no-mining zones in or near watersheds to preserve water levels and quality.

question_details.query: What are the most effective actions for improving habitat connectivity for primates in fragmented agricultural and urban landscapes?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Installing canopy crossing structures has documented benefits for primate connectivity across linear barriers in modified landscapes: black lion tamarins and capuchins used a pole bridge to cross a road; a black howler monkey population increased after pole bridges were installed over man‑made gaps; and six monitored lemur species used bridges to cross roads and pipelines [1457]. Evidence for installing vegetated wildlife overpasses (green bridges) specifically for primates has not yet been found, so their effects on primates are currently unknown [1456].
summary_statements: Installing canopy crossing structures has documented benefits for primate connectivity across linear barriers in modified landscapes.
Black lion tamarins and capuchins used a pole bridge to cross a road.
A black howler monkey population increased after pole bridges were installed over man-made gaps.
Six monitored lemur species used bridges to cross roads and pipelines.
Evidence for installing vegetated wildlife overpasses (green bridges) specifically for primates has not yet been found.
The effects of vegetated wildlife overpasses on primates are currently unknown.

question_details.query: Following captive breeding and reintroduction, over what timeframes have primate survival and population changes been documented?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Documented timeframes include: most reintroduced black-and-white ruffed lemurs with limited free-ranging experience died over five years, and most western lowland gorillas with limited free-ranging experience survived between nine months and four years [1595]. Two of three reintroduced black lion tamarins survived over four months [1596]. Most reintroduced golden lion tamarins born and reared in cages did not survive over seven years or had higher mortality than wild-born tamarins [1594]. A reintroduced chimpanzee population increased over 25 years; all Sumatran orangutans survived at least three months; a majority of reintroduced gorillas survived at least four years; a reintroduced lar gibbon population declined over three years; and a reintroduced rhesus monkey population persisted for at least four years [1590]. Across six studies, a majority of primates survived for two to thirty months, while two studies found a minority survived between three months and 12 years [1590]. Four studies found a majority of reintroduced chimpanzees survived at least one to five years; one controlled study found a reintroduced orangutan population had declined 33 years after reintroduction; one study found a primate population increased five years after reintroduction; and across multiple studies, a minority survived for at least fifteen weeks to seven years while a majority survived for at least two months to one year [1591]. Four studies reported a minority of primates survived between two months and one year after reintroduction as single/multiple individuals [1589].
summary_statements: Most reintroduced black-and-white ruffed lemurs with limited free-ranging experience died over a five-year period.
Most reintroduced western lowland gorillas with limited free-ranging experience survived between nine months and four years.
Two of three reintroduced black lion tamarins survived for over four months.
Most reintroduced golden lion tamarins that were born and reared in cages did not survive for over seven years.
Reintroduced golden lion tamarins born and reared in cages had higher mortality than wild-born tamarins.
A reintroduced chimpanzee population increased over 25 years.
All reintroduced Sumatran orangutans survived at least three months.
A majority of reintroduced gorillas survived at least four years.
A reintroduced lar gibbon population declined over three years.
A reintroduced rhesus monkey population persisted for at least four years.
Across six studies, a majority of reintroduced primates survived for two to thirty months.
Two studies found that a minority of reintroduced primates survived for a period between three months and 12 years.
Four studies found that a majority of reintroduced chimpanzees survived for at least one to five years.
One controlled study found that a reintroduced orangutan population had declined 33 years after reintroduction.
One study found a primate population increased five years after reintroduction.
Across multiple studies, a minority of reintroduced primates survived for at least fifteen weeks to seven years.
Across multiple studies, a majority of reintroduced primates survived for at least two months to one year.
Four studies reported that a minority of primates survived for a period between two months and one year after being reintroduced as single or multiple individuals.

question_details.query: To improve the effectiveness of anti-poaching patrols for primate conservation, what are the documented outcomes of providing better equipment versus providing training?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Providing better equipment to anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated, alongside other interventions, with: increased gorilla populations in a before-and-after study in the Democratic Republic of Congo and Rwanda [1476]; no gorillas killed over a 21‑month period in Uganda [1476]; and, in Rwanda, an increase in the number of immature gorillas and a decrease in snares [1476]. Providing training to anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated, alongside other interventions, with: no gorillas killed over a 21‑month period in Uganda [1477]; an increase in the number of immature gorillas in Rwanda in a before-and-after study [1477]; an increase in a hoolock gibbon population in India in a before-and-after study [1477]; and no incidents of primate poaching over a three‑year period in Cameroon [1477].
summary_statements: Providing better equipment to anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated, alongside other interventions, with increased gorilla populations in a before-and-after study in the Democratic Republic of Congo and Rwanda.
Providing better equipment to anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated, alongside other interventions, with no gorillas killed over a 21-month period in Uganda.
In Rwanda, providing better equipment to anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated, alongside other interventions, with an increase in the number of immature gorillas and a decrease in snares.
Providing training to anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated, alongside other interventions, with no gorillas killed over a 21-month period in Uganda.
Providing training to anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated, alongside other interventions, with an increase in the number of immature gorillas in Rwanda in a before-and-after study.
Providing training to anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated, alongside other interventions, with an increase in a hoolock gibbon population in India in a before-and-after study.
Providing training to anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated, alongside other interventions, with no incidents of primate poaching over a three-year period in Cameroon.

question_details.query: What is the evidence base for actions designed to reduce primate mortality and habitat fragmentation from roads and other transportation corridors?
What are the comparative outcomes of providing primates with continuous supplementary food versus providing it only during scarce periods or for a limited time?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Continuous supplementary feeding: Two studies reported population increases following regular provision alongside other interventions (China; The Gambia), while two studies reported population declines under similar circumstances (Thailand; Malaysia). Three studies reported that the majority of primates survived with regular supplementary feeding (Brazil; South Africa; Indonesia). One study reported the majority of introduced chimpanzees survived for at least one year (Liberia). One controlled study found introduced black-and-white ruffed lemurs showed different diets from a resident wild group after a year of regular supplementation (Madagascar) [1526]. Scarce-period-only feeding: One before-and-after study reported the majority of chimpanzees survived for at least five years (Republic of Congo). One before-and-after study reported wild olive baboons survived for at least 17 years after drought-period feeding soon after translocation (Kenya). One controlled study reported that black-and-white ruffed lemur diets were similar to wild individuals after scarce-period feeding (Madagascar) [1527]. Limited-time feeding: One study reported a chimpanzee population increase after two months of post-reintroduction feeding (Tanzania). One before-and-after study reported a golden lion tamarin population declined after one year following supplementary feeding (Brazil). One study reported an abandoned infant muriqui was retrieved by its mother and rejoined the wild group after feeding (Brazil). Four studies reported that only a minority of reintroduced primates survived (Brazil; Madagascar; South Africa). One study reported the majority of introduced chimpanzees survived for at least 27 months (Guinea). Three studies reported a majority of primates survived reintroduction while being supplementary fed (Gabon; South Africa; Vietnam). Two studies reported the majority of lowland gorillas survived for at least nine months to four years (Gabon; Republic of Congo) [1528].
summary_statements: Two studies reported primate population increases following regular provision of supplementary food alongside other interventions.
Two studies reported primate population declines under similar circumstances of regular supplementary food provision.
Three studies reported that the majority of primates survived with regular supplementary feeding.
One study on continuous supplementary feeding reported the majority of introduced chimpanzees survived for at least one year.
One controlled study found introduced black-and-white ruffed lemurs showed different diets from a resident wild group after a year of regular supplementation.
One before-and-after study on scarce-period-only feeding reported the majority of chimpanzees survived for at least five years.
One before-and-after study reported wild olive baboons survived for at least 17 years after drought-period feeding soon after translocation.
One controlled study reported that black-and-white ruffed lemur diets were similar to wild individuals after scarce-period feeding.
One study reported a chimpanzee population increase after two months of post-reintroduction feeding.
One before-and-after study reported a golden lion tamarin population declined after one year following limited-time supplementary feeding.
One study reported an abandoned infant muriqui was retrieved by the infant's mother and rejoined the wild group after receiving limited-time supplementary feeding.
Four studies involving limited-time supplementary feeding reported that only a minority of reintroduced primates survived.
One study on limited-time supplementary feeding reported the majority of introduced chimpanzees survived for at least 27 months.
Three studies reported a majority of primates survived reintroduction while receiving limited-time supplementary feeding.
Two studies on limited-time supplementary feeding reported the majority of lowland gorillas survived for at least nine months to four years.
